case_name: Sri Rama Vilas Service P Ltd. v. C. Chandrasekaran

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 1015 of 1963 was filed in the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 1015 of 1963. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated September 26, 1963, of the Madras High Court in Writ Appeal No. 20 of 1962.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from judgment and order dated September 26, 1963 of Madras High Court in Writ Appeal No. 20 of 1962.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated September 26, 1963, of the Madras High Court in Writ Appeal No. 20 of 1962. S. Pathak, K.K. Venugopal and R. Gopalakrishnan, for the appellant.

facts.text: Regional Transport Authority, Thanjavur called for applications for one stage carriage permit between Mannargudi and Nagapattinam.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that the Regional Transport Authority, Thanjavur called for applications for the grant of one stage carriage permit between Mannargudi and Nagapattinam. The distance between these two places is 34 miles.

facts.text: Distance between Mannargudi and Nagapattinam is 34 miles.

anchor.surface_text: The distance between these two places is 34 miles. Four applicants applied for a permit on this route. They were the appellant, Raman Raman  P  Ltd., Balasu- brahmanya Udayar, and respondent No. 1 C. Chandrasekaran.

facts.text: Four applicants for permit: appellant Sri Rama Vilas Service P Ltd., Raman & Raman P Ltd., Balasubrahmanya Udayar, respondent No.1 C. Chandrasekaran.

anchor.surface_text: Four applicants applied for a permit on this route. They were the appellant, Raman Raman  P  Ltd., Balasu- brahmanya Udayar, and respondent No. 1 C. Chandrasekaran. The Regional Transport Authority companysidered the merits of these four applicants and assigned them marks as a result of which a permit was granted to the appellant on the ground that it got the highest number of marks.

facts.text: Regional Transport Authority granted permit to appellant as it got highest marks.

anchor.surface_text: The Regional Transport Authority companysidered the merits of these four applicants and assigned them marks as a result of which a permit was granted to the appellant on the ground that it got the highest number of marks. This order was challenged by the three applicants whose applications for permit had been rejected by the Regional Transport Authority.

facts.text: State Transport Appellate Tribunal, Madras considered merits, assigned marks: appellant and Raman & Raman P Ltd. 4 marks each, others 31/2 and 3 1/4 marks.

anchor.surface_text: The State Transport Appellate Tribunal, Madras  hereinafter called the Appellate Tribunal  companysidered the merits of the four applicants for itself, assigned them marks and ultimately came to the companyclusion that the appellant was number entitled to a permit.

facts.text: Appellate Tribunal rejected appellant and Raman & Raman due to monopoly/near monopoly, granted permit to respondent No.1.

anchor.surface_text: the Appellate Tribunal took the view that the appellant was a monopolist over a distance of 18 miles which was a part of the route in question, whereas Raman Raman  P  Ltd. had a near monopoly or predominant influence over the remaining part of the distance which was 16 miles, and so, it rejected the application for a permit made by the appellant and Raman Raman  P  Ltd. and granted the permit to respondent No. 1 over the route in question.

facts.text: Appellant filed writ petition No. 25 of 1959 before Madras High Court against Appellate Tribunal order.

anchor.surface_text: It is against this order of the Appellate Tribunal that the appellant preferred a writ petition before the Madras High Court  No. 25 of 1959 .

facts.text: Srinivasan J. issued writ of certiorari quashing Appellate Tribunal order.

anchor.surface_text: Srinivasan J. who heard the writ petition came to the companyclusion that the Appellate Tribunal had signally failed to companysider the relevant evidence, and so, this order needed to be companyrected by a writ of certiorari. Accordingly, a writ of certiorari was ordered to be issued as prayed for by the appellant.

facts.text: Respondent No.1 filed Letters Patent Appeal, Division Bench reversed Srinivasan J., dismissed writ petition.

anchor.surface_text: This order was challenged by respondent No.1 by preferring on appeal under the Letters Patent before a Division Bench of the said High Court. The Division Bench has taken the view that having regard to the reasons given by the Appellate Tribunal in support of its companyclusion that the appellant was number entitled to a permit, Srinivasan J. was number justified in issuing a writ of certiorari under Art. 226 of the Constitution.

facts.text: Over first sector 18 miles, appellant runs seven buses, no other buses, so monopolist.

anchor.surface_text: It is companymon ground that over a distance of 18 miles in the first sector of the route in question, the appellant runs seven buses and numberother bus runs on that sector of the route, so that in respect of this sector, the appellant is a monopolist.

facts.text: Over second sector 16 miles, Raman & Raman P Ltd. runs nine buses, two other permit-holders run two buses, near monopolist.

anchor.surface_text: It is also companymon ground that over the second sector of the route companysisting of 16 miles Raman Raman  P  Ltd. runs nine buses, whereas two buses are run by two other permit-holders and that means that Raman Raman  P  Ltd. can be described as a near monopolist on that part of the route.

facts.text: Parallel railway between Tiruvarur and Nagapattinam offers competition to bus operators.

anchor.surface_text: the Appellate Tribunal had also failed to take into account the fact that between Tiruvarur and Nagapattinam there is a parallel railway which also offers some companypetition to the bus-operators.

facts.text: Supreme Court appeal against Division Bench order.

anchor.surface_text: It is against this order that the appellant has companye to this Court in appeal.

facts.text: Supreme Court delivered judgment on December 9, 1963 by GAJENDRAGADKAR J.

anchor.surface_text: December 9, 1963. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by GAJENDRAGADKAR J.-This appeal has been brought to this Court by special leave and it has been filed against the decision of the Division Bench of the Madras High Court by which the order passed by a learned single Judge of the said High Court directing the issue of a writ of certiorari in favour of the appellant Sri Rama Vilas Service  P  Ltd. has been reversed.

facts.text: Appellate Tribunal referred to parallel railway service.

anchor.surface_text: the Division Bench took the view that the Appellate Tribunal had referred to the existence of the amenity of the railway service parallel to the route

facts.text: Supreme Court upheld Division Bench, no writ should issue.

anchor.surface_text: In the present case, we have numberdoubt that the Division Bench was right in holding that Srinivasan J. should number have issued a writ in favour of the appellant.

facts.text: Madras Government issued administrative directions under s.43A Motor Vehicles Act.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Pathak has invited our attention to the fact that the Madras Government has issued certain administrative directions under s. 43 a  of the Motor Vehicles Act

facts.text: Administrative directions have no legal force, per Raman & Raman Ltd. v. State of Madras.

anchor.surface_text: and it has been held by this Court in M s. Raman Raman Ltd. v. The State of Madras Ors.  2  that the said administrative directions have numberlegal force and cannot be said to be binding on the appropriate authorities.

facts.text: Monopoly consideration is relevant under s.47(1)(a) Motor Vehicles Act.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, it cannot be urged that in taking into account the fact that the appellant was a monopolist on a part of the route, the Appellate Tribunal has been influenced by any irrelevant fact

facts.text: Writ petition No.25 of 1959 heard by Srinivasan J.

anchor.surface_text: Srinivasan J. who heard the writ petition

facts.text: Respondents 2 and 3 are State Transport Appellate Tribunal and Regional Transport Authority.

anchor.surface_text: Respondents 2 and 3 are State Transport Appellate Tribunal, and the Regional Transport Authority respectively and they have been impleaded because the order passed by respondent No. 2 was questioned in the writ proceedings

facts.text: Three applicants challenged RTA order before Appellate Tribunal.

anchor.surface_text: This order was challenged by the three applicants whose applications for permit had been rejected by the Regional Transport Authority.
Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated September 26, 1963, of the Madras High Court in Writ Appeal No. 20 of 1962.
writ of certiorari under Art. 226 of the Constitution. In the result, the order passed by Srinivasan J. was reversed and the writ petition filed by the appellant was dismissed.

concepts.interpretation: Jurisdiction to issue writ of certiorari against quasi-judicial authorities; High Court should not interfere with factual findings unless well-recognised tests satisfied, not act as appellate court.

under Art. 226 in cases of this kind, it is necessary to bear in mind that the High Court is not exercising the jurisdiction of an Appellate Court in the matter.
under Art. 226 and it is shown that the said decision is based on irrelevant considerations or on considerations which are invalid in law, a writ will undoubtedly be issued under Art. 226.

concepts.interpretation: Requires consideration of interests of the public generally in granting permits; assessing efficiency and adequacy of service; monopoly or near-monopoly is relevant consideration as it may lead to neglect of public interest due to lack of competition.

paramount importance under s. 47 1  a , of the Motor Vehicles Act. Besides, the Division Bench has also referred to some other aspects of the matter which would indicate that the Appellate Tribunal was right in not granting a permit to the appellant.

administrative directions under s. 43 a  of the Motor Vehicles Act and it has been held by this Court in M s. Raman & Raman Ltd. v. The State of Madras Ors.  2  that the said administrative directions have no legal force and cannot be said to be binding on the appropriate authorities.

concepts.interpretation: Administrative directions issued under this section have no legal force and are not binding on transport authorities.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: aracter. There would be obvious difficulties and causes of inconvenience for through passengers to take advantage of this hypothetical companypetition

anchor.surface_text: administrative directions issued by the Government under s. 43 a  have no force of statutory rules and are, therefore, not binding but that does not mean that the consideration that the granting of a monopoly to a bus-operator may be prejudicial to public interest, becomes irrelevant only because it has been included or is implied, in the administrative instructions.

appropriate authorities under the Motor Vehicles Act are required to consider the interests of the public generally under s. 47 1   a , and in assessing the merits of an individual applicant for a permit on any route, it would be open to the appropriate authority to enquire whether the service which the individual applicant would render to the public if he is given a permit would be efficient and satisfactory or not. In dealing with this aspect of the matter, it would not be irrelevant for the appropriate authority to hold that if any applicant is or would be in the position of a monopolist if a permit was granted to him, he would be liable to neglect the interests of the public and may not be very keen on taking all steps to keep his service in good and efficient order.

concepts.interpretation: Transport authorities perform quasi-judicial functions in granting permits; their factual decisions not to be interfered lightly under writ jurisdiction.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: decisions rendered by them on all questions of fact should number be interfered with under the special jurisdiction companyferred on the High Courts

anchor.surface_text: There is no doubt that in granting or refusing permits to applicants, the appropriate authorities are discharging a very important and a very onerous quasi-judicial function.

anchor.surface_text: There can be no doubt that in granting a permit, the appropriate authorities under the Motor Vehicles Act are required to consider the interests of the public generally under s. 47 1   a , and in assessing the merits of an individual applicant for a permit on any route, it would be open to the appropriate authority to enquire whether the service which the individual applicant would render to the public if he is given a permit would be efficient and satisfactory or not.

The Division Bench has taken the view that having regard to the reasons given by the Appellate Tribunal in support of its conclusion that the appellant was not entitled to a permit, Srinivasan J. was not justified in issuing a writ of certiorari under Art. 226 of the Constitution.

arguments.court_reasoning: No irrelevant or invalid considerations in Tribunal's order unlike that case

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ppears that the Court of Appeal took the view that the real grounds for the Tribunals decision on the section 25 point which appeared from paragraphs

holdings.text: In assessing merits under s.47(1)(a) MV Act, it is relevant to consider if granting permit to monopolist/near-monopolist applicant would lead to neglect of public interest due to lack of competition.

anchor.surface_text: There can be no doubt that in granting a permit, the appropriate authorities under the Motor Vehicles Act are required to consider the interests of the public generally under s. 47 1   a , and in assessing the merits of an individual applicant for a permit on any route, it would be open to the appropriate authority to enquire whether the service which the individual applicant would render to the public if he is given a permit would be efficient and satisfactory or not. In dealing with this aspect of the matter, it would not be irrelevant for the appropriate authority to hold that if any applicant is or would be in the position of a monopolist if a permit was granted to him, he would be liable to neglect the interests of the public and may not be very keen on taking all steps to keep his service in good and efficient order.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Public interest under s.47(1)(a) requires assessing efficiency; monopoly likely causes complacence and neglect without competition; cites prior case R.K. Ayyaswami.

holdings.text: High Court under Art.226 does not exercise appellate jurisdiction when reviewing quasi-judicial decisions of transport authorities on facts.

anchor.surface_text: under Art. 226 in cases of this kind, it is necessary to bear in mind that the High Court is not exercising the jurisdiction of an Appellate Court in the matter. There is no doubt that in granting or refusing permits to applicants, the appropriate authorities are discharging a very important and a very onerous quasi-judicial function.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Transport authorities are quasi-judicial; HC writ jurisdiction limited, not to re-appreciate facts unless well-recognised tests met.

holdings.text: Writ of certiorari should not be issued mainly or solely because quasi-judicial authority failed to set out all reasons in its order.

anchor.surface_text: Even so, it would, we think, be inappropriate for the High Court to issue a writ of certiorari mainly or solely on the ground that all reasons have not been set out in the judgment of the appropriate authority.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Authorities must give reasons, but absence of all explicit reasons not ground for certiorari if decision proper on merits; HC not to interfere lightly with facts.

holdings.text: Appellate Tribunal's decision not based on irrelevant or invalid considerations, hence no ground for certiorari under Art.226.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguishes from Ex parte Grant; Tribunal considered relevant factors like monopoly, railway; no invalid grounds.

holdings.text: Administrative directions under s.43A MV Act have no legal force and are not binding on transport authorities.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Pathak has invited our attention to the fact that the Madras Government has issued certain administrative directions under s. 43 a  of the Motor Vehicles Act and it has been held by this Court in M s. Raman & Raman Ltd. v. The State of Madras Ors.  2  that the said administrative directions have no legal force and cannot be said to be binding on the appropriate authorities.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Directly follows Supreme Court precedent in Raman & Raman Ltd. v. State of Madras.

holdings.text: Monopoly consideration does not become irrelevant merely because included in non-binding administrative directions under s.43A.

anchor.surface_text: It is true that the administrative directions issued by the Government under s. 43 a  have no force of statutory rules and are, therefore, not binding but that does not mean that the consideration that the granting of a monopoly to a bus-operator may be prejudicial to public interest, becomes irrelevant only because it has been included or is implied, in the administrative instructions.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Relevance stems independently from s.47(1)(a) public interest, not dependent on directions.

holdings.text: Division Bench correctly reversed single Judge; Srinivasan J. should not have issued writ of certiorari quashing Appellate Tribunal's order.

anchor.surface_text: In the present case, we have no doubt that the Division Bench was right in holding that Srinivasan J. should not have issued a writ in favour of the appellant.

holdings.reasoning_summary: After reviewing Tribunal order, found relevant considerations addressed; no jurisdictional error warranting interference.

holdings.text: Theoretical competition between monopolist on first sector and near-monopolist on second sector not real or effective for public interest assessment.

anchor.surface_text: On the merits, we find some difficulty in acceding that a theoretically possible competition between the monopolist and the near monopolist can have any relevance or validity in the present case.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Through passengers prefer single operator; changing buses inconvenient; hypothetical, not practical competition.

anchor.surface_text: There can be no doubt that in granting a permit, the appropriate authorities under the Motor Vehicles Act are required to consider the interests of the public generally under s. 47 1   a , and in assessing the merits of an individual applicant for a permit on any route, it would be open to the appropriate authority to enquire whether the service which the individual applicant would render to the public if he is given a permit would be efficient and satisfactory or not. In dealing with this aspect of the matter, it would not be irrelevant for the appropriate authority to hold that if any applicant is or would be in the position of a monopolist if a permit was granted to him, he would be liable to neglect the interests of the public and may not be very keen on taking all steps to keep his service in good and efficient order.

In the present case, we have numberdoubt that the Division Bench was right in holding that Srinivasan J. should number have issued a writ in favour of the appellant. We have carefully considered the order delivered by the Appellate Tribunal and we see numberjustification for the criticism made against that order that the decision of the Appellate Tribunal proceeded solely on the ground of the abstract companycept of the evil effects of monopoly.

anchor.surface_text: under Art. 226 in cases of this kind, it is necessary to bear in mind that the High Court is not exercising the jurisdiction of an Appellate Court in the matter. There is no doubt that in granting or refusing permits to applicants, the appropriate authorities are discharging a very important and a very onerous quasi-judicial function.

In the present case, we have numberdoubt that the Division Bench was right in holding that Srinivasan J. should number have issued a writ in favour of the appellant. We have carefully considered the order delivered by the Appellate Tribunal and we see numberjustification for the criticism made against that order that the decision of the Appellate Tribunal proceeded solely on the ground of the abstract companycept of the evil effects of monopoly.

anchor.surface_text: Even so, it would, we think, be inappropriate for the High Court to issue a writ of certiorari mainly or solely on the ground that all reasons have not been set out in the judgment of the appropriate authority.

In the present case, we have numberdoubt that the Division Bench was right in holding that Srinivasan J. should number have issued a writ in favour of the appellant. We have carefully considered the order delivered by the Appellate Tribunal and we see numberjustification for the criticism made against that order that the decision of the Appellate Tribunal proceeded solely on the ground of the abstract companycept of the evil effects of monopoly.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Pathak has invited our attention to the fact that the Madras Government has issued certain administrative directions under s. 43 a  of the Motor Vehicles Act and it has been held by this Court in M s. Raman & Raman Ltd. v. The State of Madras Ors.  2  that the said administrative directions have no legal force and cannot be said to be binding on the appropriate authorities.

In the present case, we have numberdoubt that the Division Bench was right in holding that Srinivasan J. should number have issued a writ in favour of the appellant. We have carefully considered the order delivered by the Appellate Tribunal and we see numberjustification for the criticism made against that order that the decision of the Appellate Tribunal proceeded solely on the ground of the abstract companycept of the evil effects of monopoly.
nch has also referred to some other aspects of the matter which would indicate that the Appellate Tribunal was right in number granting a permit to th

edges.explanation: Holding that monopoly not irrelevant despite s.43A supports no invalid considerations

anchor.surface_text: nch has also referred to some other aspects of the matter which would indicate that the Appellate Tribunal was right in number granting a permit to th

edges.explanation: Holding resolves issue on irrelevance of monopoly due to s.43A

anchor.surface_text: It is true that the administrative directions issued by the Government under s. 43 a  have no force of statutory rules and are, therefore, not binding but that does not mean that the consideration that the granting of a monopoly to a bus-operator may be prejudicial to public interest, becomes irrelevant only because it has been included or is implied, in the administrative instructions.

In the present case, we have numberdoubt that the Division Bench was right in holding that Srinivasan J. should number have issued a writ in favour of the appellant. We have carefully considered the order delivered by the Appellate Tribunal and we see numberjustification for the criticism made against that order that the decision of the Appellate Tribunal proceeded solely on the ground of the abstract companycept of the evil effects of monopoly.

In the present case, we have numberdoubt that the Division Bench was right in holding that Srinivasan J. should number have issued a writ in favour of the appellant. We have carefully considered the order delivered by the Appellate Tribunal and we see numberjustification for the criticism made against that order that the decision of the Appellate Tribunal proceeded solely on the ground of the abstract companycept of the evil effects of monopoly.
